snippet: To the Editor:   In answer to Jane Smiley's question -- how many women vividly recall the day in 1970 when Kate Millett's "Sexual Politics" liberated them from having to fake an interest in Henry Miller? -- I can go one better. Not only did I go t...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In answer to Jane Smiley's question -- how many women vividly recall the day in 1970 when Kate Millett's "Sexual Politics" liberated them from having to fake an interest in Henry Miller? -- I can go one better. Not only did I go through my bookshelves and dump a lot of male authors (D. H. Lawrence and Freud come to mind) in the garbage, but I stopped reading male authors for 10 years. It is the most liberating gift I have ever given myself. After 40 years of seeing the world -- religion, sex, politics, art, etc. -- through the filter of the male mind, it was thrilling to see it with my own eyes and brain and as women experience it.

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    The National Football League expresses concern that the Rev. Reggie White and other members of the Packers will ''use the post-game platforms for a spontaneous prayer or to make religious comments'' (''Some Packers Say The...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: The National Football League expresses concern that the Rev. Reggie White and other members of the Packers will ''use the post-game platforms for a spontaneous prayer or to make religious comments'' (''Some Packers Say They Plan to Pray Publicly,'' The Times, Jan. 24). Underlying this concern is the historic competition of religion and sports. Both vie for the same leisure time of their adherents. They share time and space and frequently adjust to each other. Several years ago, the N.F.L. abandoned its plan to begin Sunday games at 12:30 P.M. when members of the Christian clergy feared the mass exodus of male worshipers to attend kickoffs. Witness also the ubiquitous signs at pro games declaring the theology of the Gospel of John. And now the frequent claim by winners that ''God allowed me to be victorious.''
abstract: Rabbi Gerald Zelizer on NFL's expression of concern that some Green Bay Packer players might use post-game platform for a prayer or to make a religious comment, if team wins Super Bowl; holds underlying this concern is the historic competition of religion and sports

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Like most short-term travelers through Muslim countries, Nicholas D. Kristof (''Saudis in Bikinis,'' column, Oct. 25) focuses on the obvious and externals. Yes, Saudi women have no choice but to wear the black cloaks called abayas when out in public, but the real areas where they need liberation are more substantial: the travel restrictions on leaving the country without the permission of a male relative, the loss of children to husbands in divorce cases, the ''honor killings'' of daughters and sisters by fathers and brothers (often over imagined offenses), the religion police preventing girls from escaping school fires because of concerns over modesty.

snippet: Speaking as ''one Jewish woman'' to nearly 100 women struggling to practice religion and feminism, Inge Lederer Gibel made it clear this weekend that she did not intend to be robbed by a patriarchal hierarchy of a heritage she treasured.   ''In sp...
lead_paragraph: Speaking as ''one Jewish woman'' to nearly 100 women struggling to practice religion and feminism, Inge Lederer Gibel made it clear this weekend that she did not intend to be robbed by a patriarchal hierarchy of a heritage she treasured. ''In spite of the fact that Judaism, like its daughter, Christianity, and its sister, Islam, has not given women complete equality,'' she said at the conference of Women of Faith in the '80's, ''I cannot reject my heritage and its greatest scholars and sages because most of them were male, human and fallible.'' The conference was intended to bring together ''a leadership group of women of faith'' - Protestants, Catholics, Jews, Moslems and evangelicals - to talk in a supportive manner about what they have in common, what they do not and what the future may bring. Mrs. Gibel, a program specialist for the American Jewish Committee, was a coordinator of the conference. The conferees, who included nuns and rabbis, gathered for two days at the Stony Point Ecumenical Center, a cluster of low, white buildings tucked into the serene hills of Rockland County within walking distance of the Hudson.

snippet: Does religion oppress women? I think religion is part of the problem, but can also be part of the solution, and Jimmy Carter has a fascinating analysis of this question....
lead_paragraph: One of the questions that Sheryl and I get most often when we give lectures about our new book, Half the Sky, is a variant of: Is religion the real problem? My own take is that religion has often been part of the problem, but that it also can be part of the solution. I've seen people kill in the name of religion, and I've seen people reject condoms in the name of religion even as a tool for fighting AIDS (which usually means people dying). But I've also seen Catholic nuns showing unbelievable courage and compassion in corners of the world where no other aid workers are around, and mission clinics and church-financed schools too numerous to mention. And in Islamic countries, I've seen mullahs who are hypocritical misogynists but also some imams who are leading a push for education and justice. In short, I don't think there's any glib answer to the question, but there is no question that religions can be a force for justice and equality that they are now not. This magnificent new speech by Jimmy Carter on this topic makes that point very well. Excerpts:
